results.title: More tales of the city. Eps 4-6
results.creator_credit: Kevin Tierney, Productions La Fete, Channel Four Television, Working Title Films, Propaganda Films and Pierre Gang
results.brief_description: Final three episodes of this wonderful television miniseries based on the novel by Armistead Maupin. Set in 1977 San Francisco in a rundown apartment house at 28 Barbary Lane the story continues. Mrs Madrigal (Olympia Dukakis) confronts her tenants with the truth about her mysterious past and her connection to Mona (Nina Siemaszko). Mary Ann (Laura Linney) and her new love Burke (Colin Ferguson) are on a mission to recover Burke’s lost memory, whilst in the meantime Mouse (Paul Hopkins) is revisited by past love, Dr John Fielding (William Campbell). Mouse, at the same time, is struggling to come to terms with the fact that he may never be able to reveal his true “identity” to his religiously fundamentalist parents. Beauchamp Day’s (Thomas Gibson) relationship with his pregnant wife Dede (Barbara Garrick) takes a rather nasty turn with Beauchamp plotting and scheming revenge on Dede. And Dede’s mother, Frannie Halcyon (Diana LeBlanc) joins the PINUS Society - a special resort for wealthy women to celebrate their 60th birthday with the help of some rather young and gorgeous houseboys. All the ingredients are still there - the characters, the sex, the lies, the humor, the love and of course, always the drama. And the whole feel of the 1970s, love or hate the times, is so much brought back to life in the recreation of the settings, fashion and culture. An excellent series. Cast also includes Jackie Burroughs, Whip Hubley, Francoise Robertson, Domini Blythe, Swoosie Kurtz, and special appearances by Ed Asner and Sheila McCarthy.

results.title: More tales of the city. Eps 1-3
results.creator_credit: Kevin Tierney, Productions La Fete, Channel Four Television, Working Title Films, Propaganda Films and Pierre Gang
results.brief_description: Continuing episodes of the original Armistead Maupin’s television miniseries, “Tales of the city” with some old and some new cast members. Set in 1977 San Francisco in a rundown apartment house at 28 Barbary Lane, the story continues with Mrs Madrigal (Olympia Dukakis) as the mother earth landlady who’s favourite pastime is smoking and sharing her home-grown marijuana with the eclectic mix of tenants, discussing life, love and sex. Mary Ann (Laura Linney) and Mouse (Paul Hopkins) go on a cruise both in search for romance and Mr Right whilst Mona (Nina Siemaszko) feeling alone and abandoned sets off on a one way ticket to Reno, Nevada where her life is forever changed. Meantime Brian (Whip Hubley) is involved in a voyeuristic exchange with a mystery woman in another apartment block and Dede (Barbara Garrick) is pregnant with twins - but not to her husband Beauchamp Day (Thomas Gibson). If you have seen the first series, then “More tales…” must not be missed. There is drama, comedy, romance, sex, drugs, secrets and lies and a wonderful cross-section of characters that keep you totally involved in the twists and turns of the various overlay of plots. Also features an excellent support cast including Colin Ferguson, William Campbell, Jackie Burroughs, Diana Leblanc, Francois Robertson, Domini Blythe, Swoosie Kurtz and a special appearance by Parker Posey. Based on the novel by Armistead Maupin.

results.title: More space for our children
results.brief_description: Through the increase in traffic and the growth of the cities there arises the problem of what safe space can we provide for children to play in. Shows some attempts to solve this problem through kindergartens, day nurseries, playgrounds, parks, training schools and youth hostels.

results.title: More precious than gold
results.creator_credit: African Film Productions and Emil Nofal
results.brief_description: Reveals the inroads of erosion and desert on South Africa’s arable land. Shows how rivers have shrunk, bore-holes failed, and dams become silted up. Shows agricultural experts in the Bantu lands; and earth-moving equipment being used in eroded areas. Asks for the cooperation of all South Africans to “heal” their land.

results.title: More power to your elbow
results.brief_description: The handling of goods which have to be transhipped several times during their road or rail journey has always presented a problem. This film shows examples of mechanised handling which have saved warehouse space, accelerated transit of goods and resulted in the more efficient use of labour.

results.title: More power from the atom
results.creator_credit: Frank Green, Ace Films and United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority
results.brief_description: A resume of the steps which have been taken to implement Britain’s extensive atomic power-station program. Explains what the stations involve in terms of nuclear power production developments, and shows the building of the new reactors in progress and the installation of their various equipment.

results.title: More nuclear power stations = Flere atom kraftvoeker
results.brief_description: An examination of the operations required to enable nuclear power stations to function. Deals with the maintenance of reactors, the disposal of wastes and other factors related to this controversial source of energy.

results.title: More new handwriting
results.creator_credit: Diane O'Connor, Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Three related programs by Barbara Nichol on the teaching of the new handwriting style for Victorian government schools. 1.”The New handwriting”. Provides an introduction to the new handwriting course for all members of the school community. 2.”Learning handwriting”. Highlights the reasons for implementing the course. 3.”Victorian modern cursive”. Provides a demostration of the course.

results.title: More milk for more people
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, ONF | NFB and Edmund Reid
results.brief_description: The black-and-white Holstein-Friesian cattle belong to the oldest improved dairy breed in the world and are famous as record milk producers. In Canada their pedigree is safeguarded through registration and control. In this film, foreign cattle buyers are shown why this breed of cattle, raised in Canada, is a safe purchase.
